Text: The tiger doesn't have to be cunning to kill a hare.

He just needs strength. By pushing back, it makes it
impossible for the boy to fightâ€”and he's destined to
fall apart.
But that is not what happens.
Why does he look unfazed...?
Why...why can't I hit you...?

The boy's jet-black sword falls toward Grease
with unconstrained ease.

He's barely unleashed any magic or moved on his own
accord, instead choosing to go with the flow. It's as
if he's a fallen leaf swept away in a rapid stream.

Grease pools every bit of magic into his body and
sword before taking his shot. He's ready to kill
the boy, even if it costs him his life.
Terrible.
He stares at Grease, as if reading his thoughts.

Grease thought the reason behind the boy's advanced
swordplay was pure skillâ€”not magic, strength, or
speed.
But he's wrong.
What is this...this immense magical power?!
No more games.

The boy in black's unconstrained swing of his sword
hurls down on Grease with the ease of a walk in the
park.
It's a single stroke that destroys everything.

Grease watches the blade cut through his sword, his
magic, his flesh, and his bones as he stands on the
verge of death.

It's a strike fortified with impenetrable magic,
titanic strength, sonic speed, and most
importantly...natural talent.
It's perfect.

The boy in black has everything at his disposal.
But he had chosen not to use all of it until now.
Nothing could withstand that single stroke,
containing every ounce of his power.

To the trained observer, the obsydian-black sword
tells you all you need to know.  To understand who
your opponent is, just look at their sword.

His opponent appears as a serious, naive nobodyâ€”who
trained through blood, sweat, and tears to reign
victorious in battle.

Grease thought he was just a brat who knew nothing,
but he was wrong. His enemy had known everything,
and had still chosen to fight.

(...Aah...I see now... You are not just skilled...
You possess everything...)
(In the face of darkness...I was powerless...)
(But...then, this boy...must be...)
(Mi...llia...)
Grease reaches for the locket and closes his eyes.

As consciousness slips away from him, he sees the
smiling face of his beloved daughter who passed
long ago.
His strength was on another level for a bandit...

(Anyway, that's how we ended our little rescue
mission.)

(I undid my sister's chains and left her there, which
contributed to her crankiness when she returned
home the next day.)

(But she's a real tough cookieâ€”tough enough that the
wound on her hand almost healed overnight.)

(After a hectic week or so of hospital treatments and
follow-up investigations, my sister finally made her
way to the capital...)

(...though she pestered me more than usual during that
time for some annoying reason.)

(The girls in the Shadow Garden were busy. Conducting
their own research, taking care of the remaining
bandits, and other stuff.)

(Oh, right, we're not calling them bandits. Whatever.
The Cult. I mean, they're all thieves in the end.)
(But that geezer with red eyes was outstanding.)

(I mean, he inspired me to come up with "then we dive
deeper,")

(which sounds like something a shadowbroker would
say. I owe him my thanks.)

(I would've loved to have him play a supporting
role.)

(This was a must-see performance. My ability to
improvise and portray a shadowbroker was off
the charts.)

(It's a real shame there wasn't a live audience. But
I only have to wait two more yearsâ€”)

(which is when I go to the capital. You know the
one.)

(Man, I can't wait. It's a world-famous metropolis
and the only city in this country that houses one
million people.)

(I bet protagonists are a dime a dozen, and there
might be Final Bosses, too.)

(There's bound to be conspiracies, rebellions, and
incidentsâ€”none of which would ever happen here
in the boonies. And that's when the shadowbroker
bursts onto the scene...)

(I know that deep down, that's just my ego talking, but
I feel pretty good about beating those bandits. At this
moment in time, though, my prologue hasn't even
been written.)

(Well, I'll be able to go in two years' time, so if I
can get Alpha and the other girls to work hard
until then...)

(And then one day, the seven gather before me, just
as I'm yearning to get stronger for school two years
down the line.)

(They want to share their reports on the Cult and lab
findings on the curse and all that jazz.)
Shadow...
The time has come for us to leave you.
What?
This is goodbye.
Whaaat?
//Movie Play
